en.value: Lucy's bag is so nice! (The bag belongs to Lucy.)
So, [k]who[/k] do you live with, Nathan?
She lives with her wife. (She lives with her wife.)
Select the pronoun that goes with "my".
Hannah lives in a small house with her mum.
We have just learned seven ways to show possession. Here they are again:
Lucy's house is next to the station. (The house belongs to Lucy.)
To recap, here are the different words we have just learned to answer the question "Who do you live with?". You'll find them in the Vocabulary Trainer!
David lives with [k]his[/k] sister and her friend.
Mehmet says that his new house is really nice.
Hannah lives in a small house with her mum.
Neil and his partner live in a small flat.
Sure! There's a good restaurant near [k]my[/k] house.
Martha lives with her sister and some friends.
Talking about our family and who we live with - Possessives: my, your, his, her, etc.
He lives with his partner and a friend.
The words we have just seen show whom something belongs to or the relationship between two things. We call them "possessive adjectives".
Who do you live with? Write or record your response.
Read and listen to the word and the key phrase.
She lives with her boyfriend. (She lives with her boyfriend.)
She lives with her girlfriend. (She lives with her girlfriend.)
Select the words in the correct order.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Mehmet suggests a restaurant near his house.
He lives with his sister and dad.
His sister has a flat in Sydney.
Oh yeah. Who do you live with? Your sister?
Cool. I live with my sister, too. We live in a house in Brighton with some [k]friends[/k].
My [k]husband[/k] and I live in a modern flat.
Mehmet says that his sister and her partner's new house is really nice.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Select the possessive adjectives in the sentences below.
You live with [h]your[/h] sister in a small town.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Listen to the audio. Select the statement that is true.
Each possessive adjective matches a personal pronoun and the trick to using them is to learn these pairs.
Does your brother live with your mum?
Martha and Nathan are talking about who they live with.
You live with your sister in a big flat.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
It's next to the hotel in the centre of town.
Neil and his sisters live in a modern flat.
She lives with her partner. (She lives with her partner.)
Read and listen to the sentence.
My mum and I live in a flat.
I live with my [k]sister[/k] in a big flat in Bristol.
The word "partner" is a popular term that can mean "wife", "husband", "boyfriend" or "girlfriend". Look at the examples below.
No, she lives with [k]her[/k] partner now. [k]Their[/k] new house is so nice!
We live with my [k]mum[/k]. She's 84 years old.
Let's go for lunch at the weekend.
Neil and some of his friends live in a big flat.
He lives with his mum and dad.
She lives with her husband. (She lives with her husband.)
I live with my [k]partner[/k] and a friend.
We've looked at "where" we live. Now let's take a look at "who" we live with. Take a look at the examples below.
Select the possessive adjective that you hear in the dialogue.
She lives at her dad's house.

We can also show whom something belongs to by adding "apostrophe + s" to a name. In the examples below, we've added "'s" to the name Lucy, so we know that we are talking about something that belongs to her.
